content: Ignoring the politics around 1559 and forgive the ignorance, but do we have an "expected result" post-1559 implementation RE the breakdown of the aggregate end-user fee into the base fee and tip? (or another way to ask the same, how much are folks over-paying today because the price alignment mismatch). thx..

author: sky.cactus
content: Long term, what I envision is that miners all mostly set the same or similar minimum inclusion fee (like they used to do before we were persistently congested.  Wallets will monitor this and automatically set an inclusion fee that will result in landing in most blocks.  Wallets will then tell users "this transaction will cost between X and Y" where X is the base fee of next block and Y is some upper bound determined to be reasonable by the wallet by looking at historic congestion duration and projecting out worst case scenario.  Some wallets will have an advanced mode where you can limit the upper bound, and it will be capped by whatever ETH you have in your account.

author: sky.cactus
content: As far as projected total cost to users, I don't expect it to change much at all.

content: if I understand the implementation correctly ( so full disclaimer! ), the fees will escalate up in the short-term until an equilibrium is found that leave the blocks "mostly full" but also removing "most of" the bidding wars to get in a block..  I do believe in the hours after the implementation, that period will see expensive blocks (e.g. price discovery) followed by blocks that should be slighly cheaper than prior to 1559 implementation the primary difference pre- and post- being miner economics and also User Experience of what the costs are to actually be in a block..  more importantly for rollup transactions, they will have predictability to ensure they are in the upcoming block.
